column1: Ashwaubenon () is a village in Brown County in the U.S. state of Wisconsin. The population was 16
column2: 963 at the 2010 census. A suburb of Green Bay
column4: Ashwaubenon is  part of the Green Bay Metropolitan Statistical Area and carries a Green Bay mailing address. Part of the Oneida Nation of Wisconsin is in Ashwaubenon.

column1: The U.S. military bought most of the west side of Green Bay
column2: Wisconsin from the Sioux in the 1850s and 1860s
column3: except the area that would later become Ashwaubenon. That land belonged to two daughters of Chief Ashwaubamy
column4: a Sioux chief. They began selling their land to local farmers and landowners in the late 19th century. One of the owners was Jacques Vieau.

column1: One theory of the origins of Ashwaubenon is of Ojibwe origin. It is derived from ashiwabiwining "place where they watch
column2: keep a lookout". Another theory derives the name from Chief Ashwaubamay. In the Menominee language
column3: which is related to the Ojibwe language
column4: the place is known as Es-Wāpanoh
